ygData.subject: Re: Another idea for HyperNEAT application
ygData.msgSnippet: An interesting thing to mention, yesterday I was playing with my Humans experiment. I took a CPPN that produces a CTRNN exhibiting a mexican wave behaviour.

An interesting thing to mention, yesterday I was playing with my 
Humans ex=
periment. I took a CPPN that produces a CTRNN exhibiting 
a "mexican wave" =
behaviour. I scaled up the substrate to 
approximately 200 hidden nodes. Th=
e "mexican wave" pattern was 
preserved! And more, even the direction of th=
e wave was the same! 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<pe=
tar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hello, 
> 
> I was just thinking about NERO.=
 I suddenly made the connection 
between 
> the sensor placements and the s=
ubstrates for the robot experiment 
in 
> D'Ambrosio's paper. It is so simi=
lar. So I begin to think.. What 
about 
> NERO, but using HyperNEAT? The su=
bstrates can be made geometrically 
> similar to the.. enivonment, you know=
 what I mean. 
> I will try to implement a 2D version of something similar =
to NERO, 
but 
> with leaky integrator neurons, because there every node ha=
s a bias 
and 
> I don't have to care about where to place the bias unit in=
 the 
> substrate. 
> Besides, I have the following idea. During evolution,=
 in the first 
> generations (in the rtNEAT case, the first N minutes of ev=
olution), 
the 
> substrates will be simple, with low node counts. Then, gi=
ven a 
> threshold (num. of generations/time), the program will 
automatica=
lly 
> scale up the substrate to a higher density. 
> 
> Any suggestions/id=
eas about that? 
> 
> Peter
>
